sen.j: 花菱（はなびし）とは、日本の家紋である花菱紋の一種である。
sen.e: Hanabishi is a kind of Hanabisshi-mon which are used as Japanese family crests.
Hanabishi is a type of hanabishi-mon (a crest that represents the head of the Takeda family and the military governor of Kai Province) which is used as a family crest in Japan.
sen.cmt: "kind" changed to "type, " "Hanabisshi-mon" changed to "Hanabishi-mon," explanation for "Hanabishi-mon" added, plural form changed to singular form
sen.e: Hanabishi is a type of hanabishi-mon (a crest that represents the head of the Takeda family and the military governor of Kai Province) which is used as a family crest in Japan.

sen.j: 唐花紋の特に4弁の菱形のものいう。
sen.e: It is especially the rhomboidal pattern composed of 4 Kara-hana (a kind of Chinese arabesque pattern) petals.
In particular, it refers to the rhomboidal arrangement of four karahana (a type of Chinese arabesque pattern) petals.
In particular, it refers to the rhomboidal arrangement of four karahana (a type of Chinese arabesque pattern) petals.
It is also called Karahanabishi.
It is also called Karahanabishi.
It is also called Karahanabishi.

sen.j: ヒシの葉に似た文様の弁を4つ並べて花びらに見立てた形から花菱と付けられたという。
sen.e: The name Hanabishi comes from its rhombus shape which resembles a flower by arranging 4 petal-shaped pieces which look like leaves of Hishi (water chestnut).
The name hanabishi originates from the arrangement of four hishi-like (water chestnut-like) leaves as petals into a flower.
The name hanabishi originates from the arrangement of four hishi-like (water chestnut-like) leaves as petals into a flower.

sen.j: 花菱は、大陸由来の連続文様である。
sen.e: Hanabishi is a running pattern introduced from the (Asian) continent.
Hanabishi is a repeated pattern introduced from the (Asian) continent.
Hanabishi is a repeated pattern introduced from the (Asian) continent.

sen.j: 平安時代には、有識文様として公家の調度品や衣装の文様として用いられた。
sen.e: During the Heian period, it was used for furnishing goods and costumes of court nobles as Yusoku monyo (a traditional design motifs).
During the Heian period, it was used as a yusoku monyo (traditional design motifs of court nobles) for furnishing goods and costumes of court nobles
During the Heian period, it was used as a yusoku monyo (traditional design motifs of court nobles) for furnishing goods and costumes of court nobles

sen.j: 家紋としては、甲斐武田氏が始めに使用したといわれ、標準的な図案の武田花菱は武田家の定紋（じょうもん）として武田菱と同じように使用された。
sen.e: As a family crest, Hanabishi is said to have been firstly used by the Kai-Takeda clan, and Takeda-Hanabishi, which has the standard design was used as the official family crest of the Takeda family along with Takada- bishi.

It is said that hanabishi was first used as a family crest by the Kai-Takeda clan, and Takeda hanabishi, which has a standard design, was used as the official family crest of the Takeda family, just like Takedabishi.

It is said that hanabishi was first used as a family crest by the Kai-Takeda clan, and Takeda hanabishi, which has a standard design, was used as the official family crest of the Takeda family, just like Takedabishi.

sen.j: なお日本には「花菱」を屋号とする企業が複数ある。
sen.e: Incidentally, there are several companies which employ 'Hanabishi' as their Yago (a trade name) in Japan.
Incidentally, there are several companies that use "hanabishi" as their yago (trade name) in Japan.
Incidentally, there are several companies that use "hanabishi" as their yago (trade name) in Japan.

sen.j: 和家具の金具などの装飾にも用いられる。
sen.e: The pattern of Hanabishi is also used for decoration of metal fittings of Japanese furniture.
The hanabishi pattern is also used to decorate metal fittings on Japanese furniture.
The hanabishi pattern is also used to decorate metal fittings on Japanese furniture.

sen.j: 「剣（けん）」と組み合わせた「剣花菱」、丸や亀甲の枠と組み合わせた「丸に花菱」や「亀甲花菱」、正方形に変形させた「花角」など、さまざまな派生形がある。
sen.e: There are various derived patterns of Hanabishi, such as 'Ken-Hanabishi', which is a Hanabishi patten combined with swords, 'Maru ni Hanabishi', which is a Hanabishi pattern placed in a round frame, 'Kikko Hanabishi' which is a Hanabishi pattern placed in a hexagonal frame, and 'Hanakaku' which is a squre shaped Hanabishi pattern

Various patterns are derived from hanabishi, such as "ken hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern combined with swords, "maru ni hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern placed in a circular frame, "kikko hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern placed in a hexagonal frame, and "hanakaku,' which is a square-shaped hanabishi pattern.
sen.cmt: Beginning of the sentence reworded, quotation marks changed from single to double, commas placed within the quotation marks, "square shaped" replaced with "square-shaped"
sen.e: Various patterns are derived from hanabishi, such as "ken hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern combined with swords, "maru ni hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern placed in a circular frame, "kikko hanabishi," which is a hanabishi pattern placed in a hexagonal frame, and "hanakaku,' which is a square-shaped hanabishi pattern.
